resource.chars:
[The older anatomists, however, took a dif-
ferent view of the connections of the corpus callosum.
Thus, according to Gratiolet, Willis was the first 
to suggest that the corpus callosum was connected 
with the cerebral peduncles. Liedemann <s>has 
a<\s> took up the same view while Foville, by 
a certain means of dissection, considered that 
he had confirmed Willis’ idea <s>supposition <\s>. His procedure 
was that of introducing the finger between the 
corpus callosum and the edge of the gyrus fornicatus 
in a fresh brain, & running it along <s> the <\s> in the 
white substance from front to back of the 
corpus callosum. In this way he states <s>(Atlas Pl IV
P XVI fig 2 Pl XVII figs 1 & 2 Pl XIX fig II)<\s> that he has been 
able to produce preparations <s>corresponding to the 
plates he gives in his atlas <\s> of wh: he gives 
representations in Pl: XV Pl:XVI.fig 2. Pl:XVII, fig 1 & 2,
& Pl: XIX fig 1 of his atlas. They show that the 
fibres of the corpus callosum turn down towards 
the cerebral peduncles <s>and although as they
seem to be <\s> but I question very much whether 
there is not a certain amount of artificiality in preparations <s>such as he has figured can be <\s>
thus made in this rough & ready fashion. <s>But <\s>
There cannot be <s>is not <\s> the slightest doubt that Foville 
<s>was thoroughly impressed with the idea <\s> clearly held 
that some at least of the callosal fibres 
turned down into the cerebral peduncles.
